newsitem.title: FRANCE: Pilot strikes set to disturb French Easter.
newsitem.headline: Pilot strikes set to disturb French Easter.

text.p: Pilot strikes at the start and end of the long Easter weekend are set to disturb domestic flights and holiday plans at the eve of total liberalisation of French airspace.

TAT European Airlines, a unit of British Airways Plc and the main domestic rival of Air France, said on Thursday that its pilots and ground staff had called for a one-day strike on Friday whih it said would lead to heavy disturbances in its flight programme.
Earlier, two unions representing pilots and flight engineers at the Air France Europe airline called on Thursday for a two-day strike starting Monday March 31.
French airspace, up to recently dominated by Air France, will be opened up to competition from April 1 in line with European open skies rules.

In the past two years, a number of big domestic routes have already been opened to competition, leading to a big increase in flights, lower ticket prices and worsened financial results for the companies operating the lines.

Air France Europe, the former Air Inter, is being overhauled by parent Air France as part of a restructuring aimed at improving financial results and at getting the state group ready for privatisation from the end of 1997.
Air Liberte, a private airline, went into bankruptcy protection at the end of 1996 and has been taken over by TAT in a deal with Banque Rivaud. An other operator is AOM.

Air France Europe unions USPNT and SPIT said in a joint notice to Air France chairman Christian Blanc that they were protesting against the absence of negotiations on renewing a company agreement on work conditions.
Air France is taking over Air France Europe operations through a management lease agreement ahead of a full legal merger due in September.
The unions said they were opposed to the imposition of employment current at Air France, under the management lease, which harmed Air France Europe pay conditions.

They also objected to the introduction of pay measures into the whole Air France group which would hurt present and future crews, notably a double pay scale, one for current crews and a lower starting pay for younger pilots to be hired.
An Air France Europe spokeswoman said the extent of disruption would be known on Friday.
The two unions between them represent around 50 percent of the 770 pilots and flight engineers in Air France Europe.
"The Air France pilots obtained a certain number of things. We want to get the same," an official of the SPIT said.

Air France pilots last week decided to delay a four-day strike called for March 23 until May, after the company made proposals on the double pay scale which were seen open to a compromise. The delay was partly obtained after Blanc let it be know he could resign if the strike would be effected.
